title: The new simple fading with fixed stepSize reduce the code of the CALC_COLOR…
message:
The new simple fading with fixed stepSize reduce the code of the CALC_COLOR macro. This give us the opportunity to fix the old issue, that we can do multiple fades in parallel. This restriction is now removed. Additional sideaffect due performance is not investigated until now. All I did is run 4 fades in parallel (on x86 simulation!) it shows no bad effects. But it is unclear how an setFade will effect the CYCLE_TMMS while a fade is already ongoing

I removed the memset macro since it is used only in one place and is not optimized there.

title: added a reminder to add a sleep() if overwritting spi bus happens again.
message:
added a reminder to add a sleep() if overwritting spi bus happens again.
This should never happen, if timer who triggeres each ms is configured correct, and main loop never runs longer than CYCLE_TMMS.

title: Interrupt service routines ISRs have to be very fast. Imagine the timer triggers…
message: Interrupt service routines ISRs have to be very fast. Imagine the timer triggers with a frequency of 1kHz. The interrupt has to be handled in less than a millisecond. But we are running doFade() and updateFade() inside of it! On a dual core 1.6GHz X86 machine no such a problem but our PIC18 need some more time. So updateFade and doFade act like an additional postscaler for the timer! Thats why the timer isnt working as expected. I made the Commandstorage_WaitInterrupt function a macro, too. This function was much less critical than do/updateFade but we should always focus on speed inside of an ISR.

title: a second from CLI is stretched from 1000ms to 1024ms for easier calculations…
message:
a second from CLI is stretched from 1000ms to 1024ms for easier calculations inside the PIC. In a next step the interface between Client and PIC should be modified to read the timevalue N as N= 1024ms * t

reduced complexity in set fade. We allow only fading in steps of 16, this is nearly not visible to the human eye, but reduces calculation.
why 16? because stepSize * CYCLE_TMMS is the minimal garanteed fading interval = 1024ms
now, we have only one division: periodeLength = FadeTmms/numberSteps
periodeLength is the number of CYCLES have to left until one fading step is executed.

clean up include hierarchy

- using the new include hierachy is essentiel to use a real compiler like gcc, which has a few benefits. We can not only run the code on a pc for testing or simulation, but we can use the static code analysis of gcc to validate our code quality using -Wall (which is quite poor right now ;-)
